title: Aer Lingus upbeat despite increased losses
text:
Save 
Aer Lingus has seen losses increase by 40% as it prepares to be taken over by International Airlines Group. 
The Irish carrier’s operating loss before net exceptional items widened from €9.9 million to €13.9 million for the first half of its financial year. 
The drop came despite an increase in revenue of 7.4% to €749 million. Passenger numbers grew slightly (+0.3%) to 4.6 million. 
In its second quarter, Aer Lingus was hit by an adverse currency movement of €21 million. Profits in this period fell by 11% to €34.5 million. 
Stephen Kavanagh, Aer Lingus chief executive, said: “I am pleased to report a profitable second quarter with Aer Lingus well positioned to deliver an improved operating performance in the key Q3 trading period and for the full year.” 
He added: “Finally, I would like to reiterate the view of the independent directors of Aer Lingus that the combination with IAG will strengthen Aer Lingus and will grow our airline and contribute to growth in the tourism sector and wider Irish economy.”
